learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the central themes and concepts in Western political thought.
Appreciate the intellectual challenge of recovering what past authors meant by the things they wrote.
Recognise and understand the importance of conflict in the development of ideas, texts, and identities.
Understand the way disciplinary canons are formed and contested.
Be aware of the historical reception and re-interpretation of political ideas and ideals.
Be able to position key ideas and texts in relation to diverse civilisational groupings.
Appreciate the different ends of politics.
Understand the challenges and opportunities in applying their knowledge to studying contemporary political problems.
Demonstrate an ability to communicate their understanding of Western political thought through modes of written and oral expression appropriate to the discipline of politics.

assessments.task_description:
Video Presentation

Each student is required to make a video presentation (of no more than 5 minutes) analysing the vision of politics conveyed in one of the following foundational texts:

  • Plato’s Republic
  • Machiavelli’s The Prince
  • Hobbes’s Leviathan
  • Rousseau’s Discourse on Inequality


Your presentation should consider three key dimensions:

  1. The Vision of Politics: What conception of politics is articulated in the text? Consider themes such as justice, power, sovereignty, inequality, nature, or law. What is politics for, and how should it be structured or conducted? To what end?
  2. The Author’s Political Intentions: What is the main point or purpose of the text? What problem or concern is the author responding to? What kind of political change, reform, or understanding is the author seeking or legitimising? What audience(s) might they be trying to persuade?
  3. Genre and Style: How does the text’s form or genre (e.g., dialogue, mirror-for-princes, treatise, essay) or rhetorical style (e.g., irony, persuasion, satire, exhortation) shape its political argument? Is the style part of the politics or in tension with it?


Expectations:

  • Textual grounding: Anchor your claims in specific passages or ideas from the text. Quote or paraphrase as needed.
  • Historical sensitivity: Situate the author in their historical and intellectual context.
  • Clarity and structure: Present a clear argument with a logical flow. Use visuals to assist and complement the argument.
  • Timing: The presentation should be no more than 5 minutes.


**Note on AI use: While UQ in its wisdom prevents me from prohibiting AI use in assessments, I strongly encourage you to approach AI tools thoughtfully and limit their role in the preparation and writing of your essay. On submission of your video presentation, your essay, and any other written submissions for WCIV2700 you are required to fill out the course AI Declaration Coversheet.

**Information on making and uploading your video presentation: Students must upload a video version of this presentation. Instructions about filming a video and uploading it can be found on the UQ website (https://web.library.uq.edu.au/library-services/it/learnuq-blackboard-help/learnuq-assessment/blackboard-assignments).

Two software options available through UQ are Zoom and EchoVideo. If you are unfamiliar with these technologies, the Library has prepared useful guides. They are available here: 

https://web.library.uq.edu.au/library-services/it/learnuq-blackboard-help/learnuq-assessment/recording-video-assignments-zoom

https://web.library.uq.edu.au/library-services/it/learnuq-blackboard-help/learnuq-assessment/blackboard-assignments/submit-video-assignment-echovideo-original

PowerPoint may also be used to make your video presentation.

assessments.task_description:
Task Description: This is a 10-minute individual oral examination designed to assess your understanding of course texts through spontaneous discussion.

Assessment Process: You will be scheduled for an individual meeting with the course coordinator.

  1. Text selection and reading: At the start of your oral assessment, you will nominate two texts (and passages from each text) from the course readings (excluding any text that is the focus of your research essay). The coordinator will select one of your nominated texts and ask you to read aloud a selected passage from your nominated text. Bring physical copies of both selected passages to your assessment (including page numbers in the prescribed course text. Students should not bring any other printed matter to the oral assessment (eg., a prepared print-out of the opening statement or other extended notes).
  2. Opening statement: The coordinator will then ask you to provide a brief exegesis and explanation of the chosen passage.
  3. Follow-up discussion: Follow-up questions will be asked to help you expand, clarify, or deepen your initial response. The coordinator will also pose further questions asking you to relate your selected passage and text to other texts studied in the course and to broader course-related themes and concepts.


All questions are designed to give you opportunities to demonstrate your knowledge—they are not intended to trick or intimidate you.

The session will be audio recorded for assessment purposes


Preparation:

  • Review all course texts thoroughly, focusing on key arguments, themes, and concepts.
  • Select two texts as the starting point of your oral assessment.
  • Choose a specific passage from each text that you consider significant for understanding politics or a specific political concept or argument.
  • Practice articulating your thoughts about texts clearly and concisely.
  • Bring physical copies of both selected passages to your assessment
  • Be prepared to discuss any text, including the one you wrote about in your research essay


Assessment Criteria:

Content (Knowledge & Analysis):

  • Completeness and accuracy of responses
  • Demonstration of close engagement with the text
  • Quality of analysis and interpretation
  • Understanding of connections between the text and course themes
  • Breadth and depth of knowledge displayed


Communication (Eloquence & Clarity):

  • Clear oral expression and organization of ideas
  • Effective use of relevant concepts, terminology, and examples
  • Ability to construct and articulate persuasive arguments
  • Overall coherence and engagement in scholarly discussion


Note: This assessment evaluates your ability to think and communicate spontaneously about course materials, demonstrating both your understanding of the texts and your capacity to engage in scholarly discussion about course-related themes and concepts.

Introduction: Western Visions of Politics

This lecture introduces students to the course and to the study of western political thought. It will outline the contestation around the three words that make up the course title and introduce students to some of the key concepts used in political life and by political thinkers.

learning_activities.topic:
Studying Western Visions of Politics

How and why should we study the history of (western) political thought? Which texts should we study, and why? How are canons formed? By whom? And how do we engage with the selected canonical texts? This immediately poses questions of method and purpose. We will consider two rival approaches to the history of political thought: political philosophy and contextual intellectual history. What's at stake in this rivalry? Why do scholars talk about 'visions of politics'? Can these visions of politics provide solace in a disenchanted world?

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Philosophy: Plato's Republic

The lecture introduces students to Plato's Republic which is recognised by many as a foundational text of western political thought. It will examine key passages to elaborate central concepts and themes in Plato's Republic as well as consider the book's reception in Western visions of politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Philosophy: Plato's Republic

Plato's Republic is a foundational text that established the western discourse of political philosophy. Why is The Republic structured as a dialogue? How does Plato present the figure of Socrates? How does Plato conceptualise justice and the good life? What role does philosophy play in the Platonic vision of politics? Why does Plato idealise the philosopher as ruler? What are the virtues required of a ruler? Why does Plato deprecate democracy and poetry?

The Autonomy of Politics: Machiavelli's The Prince

The lecture will examine Machiavelli's The Prince, one of the most controversial texts in the history of western political thought. The lecture will discuss the genre of this text and Machiavelli's intentions, situating The Prince in relation to conventional political thought of the day.

learning_activities.topic:
The Autonomy of Politics: Machiavelli's The Prince

Machiavelli's The Prince is a classic political statement from the Italian Renaissance. Machiavelli's explosive little book built on humanist themes but scandalously rejected the notion that politics should be governed by moral-theological principles. To what extent did Machiavelli's diplomatic and political experience inform his vision of politics? What is the genre in which The Prince is written? What was his purpose? What are the virtues required of the prince? What happens to notions of justice and the good life in this vision of politics? How do virtu and Fortuna function in Machiavelli's vision of politics?

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Civil Science: Hobbes's Leviathan

The Leviathan is a monumental text of political theory written in the context of the English civil war. Hobbes's masterpiece defines and legitimises the notion of state sovereignty; a notion that has decisively shaped the modern world for better or worse. What were his intentions given the political and religious context of England and Europe? How does he construe the relationship between protection and obedience? How does Hobbes understand the office or role of sovereign? What are the virtues required of a sovereign? What function is served by Hobbes's myth of the state of nature, and what does that myth tell us about his vision of politics?

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Social Theory: Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality

The lecture will examine Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality and contextualize the political questions it addresses. The self-styled 'citizen of Geneva' argued that social institutions introduced by civilisation corrupted natural man and led to structures of inequality.

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Social Theory: Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality

Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality is concerned with the causes of inequality. He locates those causes in the political institutions and consciousness of civilised society. These have corrupted man by cultivating unnatural desires and impulses and eroding natural goodness. Rousseau thus puts the Hobbesian concept of state of nature to a very different end, explaining how political society has become so disordered.

Moralising International Politics: Kant's Perpetual Peace

The lecture will examine Immanuel Kant's essay on 'Perpetual Peace'. It will situate Kant's essay in Enlightenment themes and concepts and explain his normative critique of international politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Moralising International Politics: Kant's Perpetual Peace

Kant's celebrated essay on 'Perpetual Peace' offered a transformative vision of international relations. Drawing on Enlightenment and Revolutionary ideals of universal freedom, justice, and rights, Kant devises a project for perpetual peace that aims to transform the system of independent sovereign states into a confederation of states governed by cosmopolitan law.

Politics as Social Revolution: Marx & Engels' Communist Manifesto

The lecture will present the arguments of Marx and Engels' Communist Manifesto, one of the most influential texts of modern political thought. The critique of industrial capitalism and arguments to expand freedom and justice will be contextualised to understand the transformation of politics envisaged by Marx and Engels.

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Social Revolution: Marx & Engels' Communist Manifesto

A powerful polemic about industrial capitalism's transformation of the modern world. We examine the Manifesto's critique of political economy and its analysis in terms of class struggle. How does Marx's conception of socialism shape notions of power, freedom, civil society, the state, etc? How do Marx and Engels' use of political concepts differ from previous European thinkers? What was the purpose of this text? How did it reshape German idealist philosophy? What, if anything, does Marx's transformative vision of politics hold in common with other thinkers we have studied in this course?

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as a Vocation: Max Weber

This lecture will situate Weber's famous lecture, 'Politics as a Vocation' in relation to his earlier, and equally famous and significant lecture on 'Science as a Vocation'. In these lectures, delivered to German university students in 1917 and 1919 respectively, Weber affirmed that different spheres of life should be seen as cultivating different values and responsibilities. The lecture will outline and explain Weber's conception of politics in a disenchanted world.

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as a Vocation: Max Weber

Weber's lecture on 'Politics as a Vocation' is rightly regarded as a major twentieth-century statement on what it means to engage in politics in the modern world. Yet it raised many controversies and questions. Why did Weber conceive of politics as a vocation? What does that imply? How should political actors conduct themselves? What are the markers of political leadership? What role does charisma play in politics? What is at stake in the distinction Weber makes between an ethic of conviction and an ethic of responsibility?

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Justice: Uluru Statement from the Heart

This lecture introduces students to a contemporary Australian classic of political thought, the Uluru Statement from the Heart. It will reflect on the process of dialogue that led to the Uluru Statement and its defining political concepts and themes. It will also examine Noel Pearson's essay as a powerful example of the way western political thought has been applied to the ongoing struggles of Indigenous Australians.

learning_activities.topic:
Politics as Justice: Uluru Statement from the Heart

We examine the Referendum Council's Uluru Statement in the context of its production (ie., dialogue among Indigenous communities and colonial-settler government) and the way it handles key western political concepts and introduces Indigenous themes through the concept of Makarrata. What is the purpose of this text? What is it calling for? What is the genre of this text? What is its vision of politics? To whom is it addressed? Does it reflect the sense of crisis in western political thought? How does it relate to other historic declarations? How do its conceptions of power, authority, and truth compare to others examined in the course? To what extent does the Uluru Statement reflect or reject western visions of politics, and why?
